text: Denzel Washington is as always very good however I felt like you just can't care for his character, compared to a John Wick, there is no moment where I believed Robert Mccall was gonna lose or had any adversity, so it really didn't felt earned or good when he came out on top. However the movie is still enjoyable
Good movie, except at the end, on top of a tower high winds, rain, even the world's top sniper could not make an accurate hit in those conditions
Entertaining watch, on par with part 1 for me. Great action.

Watched all of them- this is probably the best one. Weird 3 would get all the glory, I liked that too but thought this one was slightly better. Even the first is legit. A great collection to bust out on a rainy day. Recommend.

I've been a long-time fan of Denzel Washington and have enjoyed most of his films. The Equalizer (2014) was a great start — dark, balanced, and deeply satisfying. The sequel, however, felt weaker in my opinion.

Everything that made the first movie great is still here: Robert is badass, sarcastic, and intimidating — a cold, efficient killer. The action scenes showcase this perfectly, maybe even better than in the first movie.

But two things feel out of place. First, the kid he tries to save — it feels like the writers wanted to preserve the “savior” aspect from the first film, yet it doesn’t really serve the story. That screen time could have been used to explore the conspiracy more deeply, which is the second weak point. We learn very little about it, and the final showdown in the village where Vivian comes from feels more like an excuse for cinematic scenery than a logical conclusion.

The Equalizer 2 delivers a decent story, decent action, and decent intensity — but it never comes close to the impact of the first film.
Not as good as the first one but it’s still solid
Loved the first movie, this one seems a little too convoluted, focused more on his past which may not be the thing that relates the MC to the audience.

Not a bad sequel, but a step down in quality. It suffers from a lack of plot when compared to its predecessor. The action isn't bad throughout most of the movie, but the ending felt a little overdone and unnecessary. If they took out the absurdity of the ending, I probably would have given it an extra half a star. The acting is well done, but it could've used some rewrites to deliver a much more solid film.

“This time, it’s personal… again.”

You know a movie’s in trouble when you can predict who’s going to die based on how sincere their first conversation is. The woman McCall chats with on the train? She might as well have worn a shirt that said Dead by Act Two. The filmmakers probably thought they were being clever. Sorry—I’ve seen this dance before. She’s doomed the moment she shows a flicker of warmth.

Equalizer 2 isn’t a thriller, it’s a PowerPoint presentation of clichés. People show up, say exactly what they need to say to be avenged later, then disappear until it’s time for McCall to frown, grab a hammer, and deliver justice in slow motion.

And the villains? One by one, like lemmings. They never team up, never flank, never say, “Hey, maybe don’t fight the human Terminator alone in a hurricane.” They just walk into their deaths like it’s a union gig.

The “twist” (if you want to call it that) involving McCall’s old buddy turning out to be the bad guy isn’t a twist so much as a contractual obligation. The moment he walks onscreen with that “too calm, too clean, probably evil” look, you can hear the plot thudding into place.

And what’s with the stormy final battle on an abandoned seaside town? It’s like someone said, “You know what would really elevate this flat revenge tale? Wind machines and mood lighting!”

Denzel does what he can. He always does. But even he can’t save a movie that feels like it was written by a committee with access to an AI trained solely on Liam Neeson films.

Bottom line: Equalizer 2 isn’t suspenseful. It’s a checklist. And I’ve seen this checklist before.

Just a reminder. Justice is blind. So is the script.
Everyone not mutch like this movie but the film is cool

Sucess in 2 hours and 1 minute!!!!!!!!!! Rated R for Language, Brutal Violence Throughout and Some Drug Content!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Starring Denzel Washington!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Overall, a solid action movie! The acting was mostly strong, with Denzel Washington delivering his signature tough-guy performance as an ex-hitman. However, a few scenes felt lacking in quality—particularly those involving Miles. For example, when operatives held him at gunpoint in McCall's apartment, his reaction seemed underwhelming. I expected more fear or intensity given the life-threatening situation. Despite these moments, the film was engaging and worth watching for action fans.
Great Action and i realy like when he set a stopwatch too show how fast he can kill guys!
Good action in a confused plot

The original Equalizer film with Denzel was definitely a stunner. I feel like this one was a bit of a step down, but not that far down from the original. Plus what makes it not feel like a sequel is the fact that his hair is grown in, in this film. Unless I’m missing something, it just feels like a continuity error throughout the whole movie and that’s one of the smaller reasons I gave this film one star less. Either way? Denzel Washington carried this film and I still loved it. Especially the hurricane sequence.

The formula is virtually identical to the first film, yet the globetrotting nicely illustrates how far Denzel's Robert McCall is willing to go for justice. The apartment beatdown, in particular, is a standout moment that brilliantly showcases McCall's character.
Not as good as the first movie. Slow burning. More of a murder mystery than a revenge story. Denzel is awesome as always.

A decent sequel that may slow down in action and excitement for a good middle chunk of the movie, but builds on grounded characterization and an insider deeper look into his world despite the thin direction of the plot. Denzel Washington is great as always while Pedro Pascal serves as a refreshingly different antagonist that sets him apart from the villains of the first movie. The mentorship between Denzel and the young teen was cute, even if it's final conversation after that crazy climax felt a bit thin coming from the terrified teen’s perspective. The action near the beginning was pretty entertaining and the climax set in the hurricane was a pretty cool setting. It’s not as exciting or purposeful as the first movie, but luckily there’s enough charm and care put into this to make it a decent sequel worth your time if you liked the first one.
Denzel against the world again.
It was fun but less action than the first but still good
